      • elementSize

        public ChronicleSetBuilder<E> elementSize(int elementSize)
        Configures the optimal number of bytes for an element. If elementSize is always the same, call constantElementsSizeBySample(Object) method instead of this one.

        If the size varies moderately, specify the size higher than average, but lower than the maximum possible, to minimize average memory overuse. If the size varies in a wide range, it's better to use

        Example: if element in your set(s) are English words in String form, keys size 10 (a bit more than average English word length) would be a good choice: 

        ChronicleSetBuilder<String, LongValue> wordFrequencies = ChronicleSetBuilder
     .of(String.class)
     .entries(50000)
     .elementSize(10)
     .create();
        Parameters:
        elementSize - number of bytes, taken by serialized form of the element
        Returns:
        this ChronicleSetBuilder back
        See Also:
        constantElementsSizeBySample(Object)

      • constantElementsSizeBySample

        public ChronicleSetBuilder<E> constantElementsSizeBySample(E element)
        Configures the constant number of bytes, taken by serialized form of elements, created by this builder. This is done by providing the element, all elements should take the same number of bytes in serialized form, as this sample object.

        For example, if your elements are Git commit hashes:

        Map<byte[], String> gitCommitMessagesByHash =
     ChronicleSetBuilder.of(byte[].class)
     .constantElementsSizeBySample(new byte[20])
     .create();

        If elements are of boxed primitive type or Byteable subclass, i. e. if element size is known statically, it is automatically accounted and this method shouldn't be called.

        Parameters:
        element - the sample element
        Returns:
        this builder back

      • alignment

        public ChronicleSetBuilder<E> alignment(Alignment alignment)
        Configures alignment strategy of address in memory of elements

        Useful when elements are updated intensively, particularly fields with volatile access, because it doesn't work well if the value elements cache lines. Also, on some (nowadays rare) architectures any misaligned memory access is more expensive than aligned.

        Parameters:
        alignment - the new alignment of the seta constructed by this builder
        Returns:
        this ChronicleSetBuilder back

      • alignment

        public Alignment alignment()
        * Returns the alignment memory strategy used for addresses of elements

        Default is Alignment.OF_4_BYTES.

        Returns:
        alignment memory strategy
        See Also:
        alignment(net.openhft.chronicle.map.Alignment)

      • immutableKeys

        public ChronicleSetBuilder<E> immutableKeys()
        Specifies that elements, are immutable. ChronicleSet implementations can benefit from the knowledge that elements are not mutated between queries. By default, ChronicleMapBuilder detects immutability automatically only for very few standard JDK types (for example, for String), it is not recommended to rely on ChronicleSetBuilder to be smart enough about this.
        Returns:
        this builder back
